qas.question: Who disagrees with the ideas proposed by John Harrison?
For what body of principles is it debated whether or not it was constructed according to the rule of law?
According to John Harrison, through the Constitution, what is law?
According to Frederick Mark Gedicks, who believed that unjust laws were not really laws?

answers.text: the framers of the U.S. Constitution

qas.question: Who argues over whether the U.S. Constitution adopted the rule of law?
What law professor says the Constitution does it meet either the formal or substantive?

plausible_answers.text: Thomas Aquinas, and the framers of the U.S. Constitution

qas.question: Who believed that an unjust law was still a law?
The framers of the Constitution say did not have discretion to decide which laws submit such vague criteria?

context: <b4_0>Scholars<b4_0/> continue to debate whether the <a1_0>U.S. Constitution<a1_0/> adopted a particular interpretation of the "rule of law," and if so, which one. For example, John Harrison asserts that the word "law" in the Constitution is simply defined as <a2_0>that which is legally binding<a2_0/>, rather than being "defined by formal or substantive criteria," and therefore <b7_0>judges<b7_0/> do not have discretion to decide that laws fail to satisfy such unwritten and vague criteria. <a0_0>Law Professor <b5_0>Frederick Mark Gedicks<b5_0/><a0_0/> disagrees, writing that Cicero, Augustine, <b6_0>Thomas Aquinas, and <a3_0>the framers of the U.S. Constitution<b6_0/><a3_0/> believed that an unjust law was not really a law at all.
